Module 10: Multiple Choice Questions

For students

Last updated: 09/01/2026 12:21

The questions are based on or inspired by the following references:

  • Berk & DeMarzo, Corporate Finance, 5th ed. (2020)
  • Brealey & Myers, Principles of Corporate Finance, 13th ed. (2020)

üí° You can also press Ctrl + P (or Cmd + P on Mac) to print or save your responses as a .pdf file.

‚ö†Ô∏è These exercises are powered by AI-assisted technologies and may contain occasional formatting or logic errors. Please report any issues you encounter so I can improve the experience.

üìô Part 2 (Midterm to Final)

Module
10

Select the correct answers.

Q1.

Which of the following best describes the ex-dividend date?






‚úÖ B is correct. The ex-dividend date is the cutoff date‚Äîinvestors who buy on or after this date will not receive the declared dividend.

Q2.

What does Modigliani and Miller‚Äôs dividend irrelevance theory state?






‚úÖ A is correct. MM Proposition I with payout states that in perfect markets, dividend policy has no impact on firm value‚Äîthe choice between dividends and repurchases is irrelevant.

Q3.

Which statement about share repurchases is true?






‚úÖ D is correct. Repurchases are a method for returning excess cash to shareholders, similar in purpose to dividends but with different tax and signaling effects.

Q4.

What typically happens to a company‚Äôs stock price on the ex-dividend date?






‚úÖ C is correct. On the ex-dividend date, the stock price typically drops by about the dividend amount, reflecting that new buyers are no longer entitled to receive it.

Q5.

What is a firm‚Äôs payout policy primarily concerned with?






‚úÖ E is correct. Payout policy determines how a firm returns excess free cash flow to shareholders‚Äîvia dividends, share repurchases, or retention.

Q6.

Which of the following is an advantage of a share repurchase compared to a cash dividend?






‚úÖ A is correct. Repurchases give investors control over realizing capital gains, which are often taxed more favorably and only upon sale.

Q7.

Under the current Brazilian tax system, which statement about dividend taxation is correct?






‚úÖ A is correct. In Brazil, dividends distributed by domestic corporations are generally exempt from personal income tax for resident individuals, while capital gains are taxed and interest on equity (JCP) is subject to withholding tax. This can make dividends relatively more attractive than share repurchases for local investors.

Q8.

Which of the following describes dividend smoothing?






‚úÖ D is correct. Dividend smoothing refers to management‚Äôs tendency to maintain relatively stable dividend payments over time, even when earnings are volatile.

Q9.

What is the main idea behind the dividend signaling hypothesis?






‚úÖ E is correct. Under the dividend signaling hypothesis, increases or decreases in dividends reveal management‚Äôs private information about expected future profitability.

Q10.

Why might a firm perform a stock split?






‚úÖ B is correct. Stock splits make shares more affordable and can improve trading liquidity by keeping the price in a desirable range for retail investors.

Q11.

Which of the following best describes the clientele effect?






‚úÖ C is correct. The clientele effect suggests that investors self-select into firms whose dividend policies match their tax situations or cash flow preferences.

Q12.

Why might managers prefer share repurchases to cash dividends?






‚úÖ B is correct. Repurchases allow firms to return cash without committing to ongoing payouts and can act as a signal that management believes the stock is undervalued.

Q13.

According to MM‚Äôs payout irrelevance theory, which assumption must hold?






‚úÖ A is correct. MM‚Äôs dividend irrelevance requires perfect capital markets‚Äîno taxes, transaction costs, or asymmetric information‚Äîso payout choice does not affect value.

Q14.

Which of the following represents an agency cost of retaining excess cash?






‚úÖ D is correct. Retaining too much cash can lead to managerial inefficiency or overinvestment‚Äîan agency cost of free cash flow.

Q15.

What is the key difference between a stock dividend and a stock split?






‚úÖ E is correct. Both increase shares outstanding without changing total equity value, but splits are larger adjustments intended to keep share prices attractive.

Q16.

Which of the following best explains why firms might retain cash rather than distribute it to shareholders?






‚úÖ B is correct. Firms often retain cash to finance future investments internally and avoid the issuance costs or constraints of external financing.

Q17.

What happens to the stock price immediately after a firm pays a cash dividend in perfect capital markets?






‚úÖ E is correct. In perfect markets, when cash leaves the firm as a dividend, the stock price drops by roughly the same amount to reflect the reduced assets.

Q18.

Which of the following statements about share repurchases is FALSE?






‚úÖ C is correct. Share repurchases do not inherently increase firm value‚Äîthey merely redistribute cash to shareholders under certain tax and signaling conditions.

Q19.

Which of the following is TRUE regarding dividend taxes?






‚úÖ A is correct. Dividend income is taxed in the year received, while capital gains taxes can be deferred until shares are sold, making dividends less tax-efficient.

Q20.

What typically motivates a firm to announce a share repurchase?






‚úÖ D is correct. Firms often repurchase shares to signal that management believes the stock is undervalued, consistent with signaling theory.

Q21.

Which of the following best defines the ex-dividend date?






‚úÖ C is correct. The ex-dividend date is the cutoff: investors who buy the stock on or after this date do not receive the declared dividend.

Q22.

Why might a firm issue a special dividend?






‚úÖ B is correct. Firms may issue special dividends to return excess cash that arises from extraordinary profits or the sale of assets, without changing their regular payout policy.

Q23.

Which of the following is a potential drawback of maintaining a high dividend payout ratio?






‚úÖ D is correct. High dividend payouts can constrain internal financing and reduce the firm‚Äôs capacity to fund future profitable investments.

Q24.

According to the dividend capture theory, who benefits most from buying shares just before the ex-dividend date?






‚úÖ A is correct. Investors with low or no dividend tax liability may temporarily buy shares before the ex-dividend date to capture the dividend without suffering a tax disadvantage.

Q25.

Which of the following best describes a stock split?






‚úÖ E is correct. A stock split multiplies the number of shares outstanding but leaves the total equity value unchanged, mainly to maintain an optimal price range for trading liquidity.

Q26.

Why might investors prefer firms that pay stable dividends?






‚úÖ B is correct. Many investors value predictable income streams and perceive stable dividends as a signal of consistent profitability and management confidence.

Q27.

Which of the following scenarios is most consistent with the signaling theory of dividends?






‚úÖ E is correct. Dividend increases often signal management‚Äôs confidence in sustainable future earnings, consistent with signaling theory.

Q28.

Which of the following best describes the effect of taxes on payout policy?






‚úÖ A is correct. When dividends are taxed more heavily than capital gains, firms tend to rely more on share repurchases for distributing cash to shareholders.

Q29.

Which statement about Interest on Equity (Juros sobre Capital Pr√≥prio, JCP) in Brazil is TRUE?






‚úÖ B is correct. Under Brazilian law, Interest on Equity (JCP) is tax-deductible for the firm‚Äîreducing taxable income‚Äîbut it is subject to a withholding income tax for shareholders. This makes JCP a hybrid mechanism combining features of dividends and interest payments.

Q30.

Which of the following is most likely an example of agency conflict related to payout policy?






‚úÖ D is correct. Retaining excess cash may allow managers to pursue self-serving projects or perks rather than maximizing shareholder value.

Q31.

Which of the following is a likely reason firms avoid cutting dividends?






‚úÖ C is correct. Managers are reluctant to cut dividends because investors often interpret such actions as a signal of financial weakness or declining future profitability.

Q32.

How do taxes create a preference for capital gains over dividends for many investors?






‚úÖ E is correct. Capital gains are typically taxed only when realized and often at lower rates, giving investors a tax advantage over immediately taxable dividends.

Q33.

Which of the following statements about payout policy is TRUE?






‚úÖ B is correct. Payout policy involves a trade-off between rewarding shareholders and retaining funds for future profitable investment opportunities.

Q34.

What is one possible reason a firm might prefer to pay dividends rather than repurchase shares?






‚úÖ A is correct. Firms may pay dividends to appeal to investors seeking stable income streams, consistent with clientele effects and investor preferences.

Q35.

Which of the following would most likely decrease a firm‚Äôs payout ratio?






‚úÖ D is correct. Firms may reduce payout ratios to retain funds for growth investments, lowering cash distributions to shareholders.

Q36.

According to the life-cycle theory of dividends, which firms are most likely to pay dividends?






‚úÖ C is correct. According to the life-cycle theory, mature firms with steady cash flows and limited investment needs are more likely to distribute dividends.

Q37.

What effect might a share repurchase have on earnings per share (EPS)?






‚úÖ D is correct. Share repurchases reduce the number of outstanding shares, which can raise EPS if total earnings remain constant.

Q38.

What typically happens to a firm‚Äôs cash balance after paying a cash dividend?






‚úÖ B is correct. Paying cash dividends reduces the firm‚Äôs cash balance by the payout amount since funds are transferred to shareholders.

Q39.

Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding stock dividends?






‚úÖ A is correct. Stock dividends distribute additional shares to existing shareholders, increasing share count but leaving total firm value unchanged.

Q40.

Which of the following is NOT a likely motivation for a firm to repurchase shares?






‚úÖ E is correct. In perfect markets, repurchases do not inherently increase firm value‚Äîthey redistribute cash without changing total firm wealth.

Q41.

What is the main advantage of using share repurchases instead of dividends to distribute cash to shareholders?






‚úÖ B is correct. Share repurchases are more flexible than dividends and may offer tax advantages when capital gains are taxed less than dividends.

Q42.

Which of the following best defines the ex-dividend date?






‚úÖ D is correct. The ex-dividend date is when the stock starts trading without the right to receive the next dividend payment.

Q43.

What is the typical market reaction to an unexpected increase in dividends?






‚úÖ A is correct. An unexpected dividend increase is often interpreted as a positive signal about management‚Äôs expectations of future earnings.

Q44.

What happens to the stock price when a dividend is paid in perfect capital markets?






‚úÖ C is correct. In perfect capital markets, the share price drops by roughly the amount of the dividend on the ex-dividend date, reflecting the cash paid out to shareholders.

Q45.

Which statement is TRUE regarding stock spin-offs?






‚úÖ E is correct. In a spin-off, shareholders of the parent firm receive shares in the new independent company, maintaining overall value while separating operations.

Q46.

Which of the following statements best explains the clientele effect in dividend policy?






‚úÖ B is correct. The clientele effect suggests that investors with different tax brackets or income needs prefer firms with dividend policies that suit their situations.

Q47.

What is the likely effect of a stock split on a firm‚Äôs market capitalization?






‚úÖ A is correct. A stock split increases the number of shares while proportionally reducing the share price, leaving total market capitalization unchanged.

Q48.

Why might a firm hold excess cash instead of paying dividends?






‚úÖ D is correct. Firms may retain cash to finance future projects internally, reducing reliance on external capital markets and potential financial distress.

Q49.

In Modigliani and Miller‚Äôs framework, which assumption is crucial for dividend policy irrelevance?






‚úÖ E is correct. Dividend irrelevance relies on perfect capital markets where taxes, transaction costs, and asymmetric information are absent.

Q50.

What is a reverse stock split (inplit)?






‚úÖ C is correct. A reverse split, or inplit, reduces the number of outstanding shares while increasing the price per share, often to meet exchange listing requirements or improve perception.

Q51.

Which of the following statements best describes dividend smoothing?






‚úÖ D is correct. Dividend smoothing refers to firms maintaining relatively constant dividend payments, avoiding frequent adjustments in response to short-term earnings changes.

Q52.

Which of the following factors most likely influences a firm to initiate dividend payments?






‚úÖ A is correct. Firms with stable profitability and limited investment opportunities often initiate dividends as a way to return excess cash to shareholders.

Q53.

Which of the following statements about Modigliani and Miller‚Äôs dividend irrelevance theory is TRUE?






‚úÖ E is correct. MM‚Äôs theory holds that in perfect capital markets, dividend policy is irrelevant because investors can replicate payouts by selling shares (homemade dividends).

Q54.

What is a key implication of the dividend signaling hypothesis?






‚úÖ B is correct. The signaling hypothesis suggests that dividend increases convey management‚Äôs positive outlook on the firm‚Äôs future performance.

Q55.

Which of the following represents an agency cost of retaining excess cash?






‚úÖ C is correct. Retaining excessive cash can create agency costs if managers misuse funds in unprofitable projects or perks that do not benefit shareholders.

Q56.

What is a potential benefit of paying out cash through share repurchases instead of dividends?






‚úÖ D is correct. Share repurchases provide flexibility, as they do not establish a long-term payout commitment and may offer tax benefits relative to dividends.

Q57.

Which of the following is TRUE regarding a reverse stock split (inplit)?






‚úÖ A is correct. A reverse split consolidates existing shares into fewer, higher-priced shares without changing total market capitalization.

Q58.

Why might a firm prefer to retain cash rather than distribute it as dividends?






‚úÖ C is correct. Retaining cash allows firms to finance new projects internally, reducing dependence on costly external capital and minimizing financing constraints.

Q59.

Which statement best describes the dividend capture theory?






‚úÖ B is correct. Dividend capture theory suggests that investors with low tax rates temporarily buy shares before the ex-dividend date to benefit from after-tax dividend gains.

Q60.

Which of the following statements about the tax disadvantage of dividends is TRUE?






‚úÖ E is correct. When dividends are taxed more heavily than capital gains, investors and firms prefer share repurchases to reduce tax liabilities.

Q61.

What is the main reason firms engage in share repurchases?






‚úÖ C is correct. Share repurchases allow firms to return cash to shareholders without committing to regular payouts, preserving flexibility.

Q62.

Which of the following statements about dividend policy is TRUE?






‚úÖ D is correct. Dividend smoothing reflects management‚Äôs effort to maintain predictable dividend payments despite earnings fluctuations.

Q63.

Which of the following is an example of a non-cash payout to shareholders?






‚úÖ B is correct. A stock dividend distributes additional shares instead of cash, leaving total shareholder value unchanged.

Q64.

Which of the following investors would most likely prefer dividend-paying stocks?






‚úÖ E is correct. Retirees and income-focused investors often prefer dividends for predictable cash flow, forming part of the clientele effect.

Q65.

Which of the following best defines the clientele effect?






‚úÖ C is correct. The clientele effect refers to how investors self-select firms whose dividend policies align with their tax situations and income needs.

Q66.

Which statement best describes the tax preference for share repurchases?






‚úÖ A is correct. Share repurchases may be tax-preferred because capital gains are taxed at lower rates and only upon realization, unlike dividends taxed when received.

Q67.

Which of the following would most likely reduce the potential for agency costs in a firm with excess cash?






‚úÖ D is correct. Paying out excess cash reduces free cash flow available for managerial misuse, thereby lowering potential agency costs.

Q68.

Which of the following best explains why a company might perform a reverse stock split (inplit)?






‚úÖ E is correct. A reverse stock split consolidates shares to raise the trading price, often done to meet stock exchange minimum price requirements.

Q69.

Which of the following is TRUE regarding the ex-dividend date?






‚úÖ B is correct. The ex-dividend date marks when a stock starts trading without the right to the upcoming dividend; purchases after this date do not receive the declared payment.

Q70.

Which of the following statements best describes the dividend puzzle?






‚úÖ C is correct. The dividend puzzle refers to the continued popularity of dividends even though they are often less tax-efficient than share repurchases.

Q71.

Aurora Energy‚Äôs stock trades at $45 cum-dividend. The firm announces a $2 dividend. Assuming perfect capital markets and no taxes, what should be the ex-dividend price?






‚úÖ A is correct. In perfect capital markets, the stock price falls by the dividend amount: $ P_{ex} = 45 - 2 = 43 $.

Q72.

NovaTech Industries has 10 million shares outstanding and $50 million in excess cash. If it distributes the cash as a special dividend, what is the dividend per share?






‚úÖ C is correct. Dividend per share = $50M / 10M = $5.00.

Q73.

Orion Systems has 10 million shares outstanding, a share price of $45, and $50 million in excess cash to repurchase shares. How many shares will be repurchased?






‚úÖ C is correct. Shares repurchased = $50M / $45 = 1.11M shares, leaving about 8.89M outstanding.

Q74.

If the dividend tax rate is 40% and the capital gains tax rate is 20%, what is the effective dividend tax rate?






‚úÖ B is correct. $ ^* = 1 - = 1 - = 0.25 = 25% $.

Q75.

Vega Motors‚Äô shares trade at $200 each. The company wants to reduce the price to $80 through a stock split. What split ratio should it use?






‚úÖ C is correct. Ratio = \(200 / 80 = 2.5\), which corresponds to a 5-for-2 stock split.

Q76.

Solaris Corp has 12 million shares outstanding and earns $60 million per year. If it uses $30 million to repurchase shares at $50 each, what will be the new earnings per share (EPS)?






‚úÖ D is correct. Shares repurchased = $30M / $50 = 0.6M; new shares = 12 ‚àí 0.6 = 11.4M. EPS = $60M / 11.4M = $5.26 ‚âà $5.36.

Q77.

Aurora Holdings‚Äô stock trades at $60 cum-dividend. The firm pays a $3 dividend. If the dividend tax rate is 30% and the capital gains tax rate is 15%, what is the expected ex-dividend price?






‚úÖ B is correct. Using \((P_{cum} - P_{ex}) = Div √ó (1 - œÑ_d)/(1 - œÑ_g)\) ‚Üí \(3 √ó 0.7/0.85 = 2.47\), so \(P_{ex} = 60 ‚àí 2.47 = 57.53 ‚âà 57.5\).

Q78.

If Horizon Ltd. has 20 million shares trading at $25 each and decides to pay a $0.50 dividend, what is the firm‚Äôs market capitalization after the dividend payment (assuming no taxes)?






‚úÖ A is correct. Total before = $25 √ó 20M = 500M; after payment, price drops by $0.50 ‚Üí $24.5 √ó 20M = 490M.

Q79.

NovaChem shares trade at $30 at the beginning of the year and $33 at the end. The company paid a $1 dividend during the year. What was the total shareholder return?






‚úÖ E is correct. Return = (33 ‚àí 30 + 1) / 30 = 4 / 30 = 13.3%.

Q80.

Lumen Industries performs a 1-for-5 reverse split (inplit). If an investor holds 2,000 shares at $2 each before the split, how many shares and what price will they have afterward?






‚úÖ D is correct. In a 1-for-5 reverse split, every 5 shares become 1. 2,000 √∑ 5 = 400 shares, each priced at $10 to keep value unchanged ($800 total).

Q81.

Atlas Corp has $10 million in excess cash. It can either pay the dividend now or invest the funds in Treasury bills yielding 5% for one year. In a perfect capital market, what is the effect on shareholder wealth?






‚úÖ C is correct. In perfect markets, investors can replicate the firm‚Äôs actions by investing dividends themselves‚Äîtiming of payout does not affect total wealth.

Q82.

If a firm faces a 35% corporate tax rate, a 20% capital gains tax, and investors earn 4% interest, what is the effective tax cost of retaining cash, œÑ*retain?






‚úÖ B is correct. Using \(\tau^*_{retain} = 1 - \frac{(1 - \tau_c)(1 - \tau_g)}{(1 - \tau_i)}\) ‚Üí \(1 - \frac{(0.65)(0.8)}{0.96} = 0.28 = 28\%.\)

Q83.

At the start of the year, Zenith Co. shares trade at $50 and pay a $2 dividend. What is the dividend yield?






‚úÖ A is correct. Dividend yield = Dividend / Price = 2 / 50 = 4%.

Q84.

Helios Industries repurchases shares worth $40 million when its equity is valued at $400 million. What fraction of its shares will be repurchased?






‚úÖ D is correct. Repurchased fraction = \(40M / 400M = 10\%\).

Q85.

Before paying a $1 dividend, Polaris Inc. has 50 million shares trading at $40. Assuming no taxes, what is the firm‚Äôs total market value immediately after the dividend?






‚úÖ E is correct. Before payout: $50M √ó $40 = \(2.0B\); ex-dividend price = $39 ‚Üí $39 √ó 50M = \(1.95B\).

Q86.

Aurora Energy‚Äôs stock trades at $70 cum-dividend. The firm pays a $4 dividend, and dividend tax is 25% while capital gains tax is 15%. What is the expected ex-dividend price?






‚úÖ A is correct. \((P_{cum} - P_{ex}) = Div √ó (1 - œÑ_d)/(1 - œÑ_g) = 4 √ó 0.75/0.85 = 3.53\), so \(P_{ex} = 70 ‚àí 3.53 = 66.47 ‚âà 66.7\).

Q87.

Stellar Motors has 8 million shares trading at $50. It repurchases $40 million worth of shares. Assuming no taxes, what is the share price after the repurchase?






‚úÖ C is correct. In perfect capital markets, a share repurchase does not change share price‚Äîonly reduces shares outstanding.

Q88.

Nova Foods retains $10 million cash and invests at 4% after tax. Alternatively, it could pay the dividend now. If investors can earn 4% after tax, what is the change in shareholder wealth after one year?






‚úÖ D is correct. In perfect markets with identical after-tax returns, retaining or distributing cash has no effect on shareholder wealth.

Q89.

Orion Group executes a spin-off worth $60 million. Before the spin-off, total equity value was $600 million. What happens to shareholder wealth after the spin-off?






‚úÖ B is correct. In a spin-off, shareholders receive new shares in the subsidiary; total value remains constant at $600M, only redistributed.

Q90.

Helios Inc. expects free cash flows of $120 million per year and maintains a 40% payout ratio. With a 10% cost of capital and no growth, what is the firm‚Äôs equity value?






‚úÖ E is correct. Value = FCF / r = $120 / 0.10 = $1,200M = \(1.2B\). Payout ratio does not change valuation in no-growth scenario.

Q91.

Vega SA has shares trading at $60. The firm announces a $3 dividend or an equivalent $3 share repurchase. In perfect capital markets, what happens to the share price in each case?






‚úÖ B is correct. In perfect capital markets, payout form is irrelevant‚Äîprice drops by the dividend amount in either case.

Q92.

If Orion Ltd. stock rises from $40 to $44 and pays a $1 dividend during the year, what is the total return to shareholders?






‚úÖ A is correct. Total return = (44 ‚àí 40 + 1)/40 = 5/40 = 12.5%.

Q93.

A firm pays a $2 dividend, œÑd = 35%, and œÑg = 20%. What is the effective dividend tax rate œÑ*d?






‚úÖ D is correct. \(œÑ^*_d = (œÑ_d ‚àí œÑ_g)/(1 ‚àí œÑ_g) = (0.35 ‚àí 0.20)/(0.80) = 0.1875 = 18.75\%.\)

Q94.

A firm executes a 2-for-1 stock split. If an investor owns 500 shares at $100 each, what will be the number of shares and price after the split?






‚úÖ E is correct. After a 2-for-1 split, shares double and price halves: \(500 √ó 2 = 1,000\) shares at $100/2 = \(50\) each.

Q95.

An investor buys a stock for $80. After one year, the price is $84 and the firm pays a $2 dividend. What is the effective dividend yield?






‚úÖ C is correct. Dividend yield = \(2 / 80 = 2.5\%.\)

Q96.

A firm retains $5 million in cash instead of paying it out. If the corporate tax rate is 40% and interest income is taxed at 20%, what is the tax cost of retaining cash?






‚úÖ B is correct. \(œÑ^*_{retain} = 1 - (1 - 0.4)(1 - 0.2) = 1 - 0.48 = 0.28 = 28\%.\)

Q97.

A firm generates $100 million in FCF each year and retains 30%. Assuming no taxes and a 10% cost of capital, what is the value of the firm?






‚úÖ A is correct. With constant \(FCF = 100M\), \(V = FCF / r = 100 / 0.10 = 1,000M\). Retention doesn‚Äôt affect valuation if no taxes or growth.

Q98.

If dividend per share is $3, earnings per share $6, and price $60, what is the payout ratio and dividend yield?






‚úÖ D is correct. Payout = 3/6 = 50%; Yield = 3/60 = 5%.

Q99.

After paying a $1 dividend, Aurora Tech‚Äôs shares drop from $50 to $49. If an investor owns 2,000 shares, what is the change in total portfolio value?






‚úÖ E is correct. The investor receives $1 √ó 2,000 = \(2,000\) in dividends, offsetting the \(2,000\) price drop‚Äîno change in total wealth.

Q100.

If dividends grow at 5% per year, payout ratio is 60%, and cost of equity is 10%, what is the P/E ratio implied by the Gordon growth model?






‚úÖ C is correct. Using \(P/E = payout / (r - g) = 0.6 / (0.10 - 0.05) = 12\).

Group 1 of 20
